repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
**feat(marks): add conceal_lines to nvim_buf_set_extmark()**

Implement an extmark property that conceals lines vertically.

**feat(treesitter): vertical conceal for conceal nodes**

TSHighlighter now places marks for conceal_lines metadata. A new
internal decor provider callback _on_conceal_line was added that
instructs the highlighter to place conceal_lines marks whenever the
editor needs to know whether a line is concealed. The bundled markdown
queries use `conceal_lines` metadata to conceal code block fence lines.

Work on #25718

comment_data.body: is `moved` for the cursor? perhaps `cursor_moved` is more explicit
perhaps this should be checked directly in `win_update()` ? avoids the extra return value .
callsites still expect `foldedp` to be set (I get UBSAN errors otherwise), could  use `if (foldedp) { *foldedp = false; }`

Yes but the argument only made sense for cursor movement to the an adjacent line, so I removed it (and replaced it with separate calls).

EDIT: Added it back to aggregate early cursorline returns, except when we also need to check to previous cursor position. (Still doesn't affect the range anymore).
Does this work if you move it to `redraw_for_cursorline()`?
Unfortunately it doesn't. I checked that before and debugged why it doesn't but forgot the exact reason x)

On a side note regarding the TODO here: toggling conceal line visibility is similar to open/closing a fold which also just redraws the entire window (`changed_window_setting()`), where partial/scroll redraws should be possible.
(So maybe not critical to resolve initially.)

EDIT: I adjusted some logic regarding scroll redrawing to account for concealed lines when in the case of just scrolling that doesn't toggle conceal line visibility.

Now no longer sure we can do partial redraws when toggling line visibility; maybe fold actions do this because we can no longer use `w_lines` at all (or is too involved (could perhaps invalidate individual `w_lines` entries?)). At least currently when just marking this with `UPD_SOME_VALID`, the `win_update()` logic fails to find the scroll cutoff and just redraws everything anyways.

In that case, I think this is ready for review.

```suggestion
                  • conceal_line: string (empty or a
                    single character). When provided, lines in the range are not
                    drawn at all; the next unconcealed line is drawn instead.
```
(Assuming that a non-empty string is simply ignored at the moment, meaning the behavior is the same.)

comment_data.body:
Is this still preserved? This line effectively jumps over folded lines and prevents slowness when rendering very large folds.

Basically, it is faster to create a new iterator than to traverse it if the distance is big enough. Instead of introducing any heuristics, we decided to just refresh the iterator whenever we hit a fold.

> If anything wouldn't it be less performant due to the intermediate structure?

For transparency: this seems to be true in the case of many captures, I tested in a markdown file before.
With the C parser, in a large window, this refactor loses out to HEAD by ~5%.
So it depends on the situation, but I think it's the best we can do. Without the perf commit, this feature would introduce a greater performance hit.

comment_regular_data.body: I think a single new `'conceallevel'` value isn't enough to control this. One may want `conceal_lines` to work in combination with any of the existing `'conceallevel'` values.
Ye wasn't sure about that yet either, was just following #25718 for now and using `4` to test toggling.

On the other hand, I don't think this (combining different levels) is common enough to warrant a new option. The main (and right now only) use for this is completely hiding code block markers in Markdown.

If you feel strongly about being able to hide only those lines, we could do the "bitflag" approach and add, say, 4 to each level to include vertical conceal (so 4 only hides lines, 7 is level 3 with hidden lines etc.)

> use for this is completely hiding code block markers in Markdown.

This requires a combination of `&conceallevel = 2` and `conceal_lines`, which is already a combination that this PR doesn't currently support.

So why add a new level at all? Why not just add `conceal_lines` to existing levels?

Yeah going by the current help text for 'conceallevel', hiding concealed lines seems to fit fine with the current levels. Might be a bit surprising to have this enabled without user intervention but perhaps some kind of indicator on the next line similar to the 'smoothscroll' indicator can help with that?

> So why add a new level at all? Why not just add conceal_lines to existing levels?

That also works, and is probably the easiest for the MVP here.

Current open questions:
* What column should the cursor be at when it is on a concealed line (0 or actual `wcol` it would be at if it wasn't hidden).
* What should happen when the first line of a closed fold is concealed. For now I assume that would hide the line with foldtext and thus the entire fold.
* Do we need an indicator for concealed lines (with `set no(r)nu`).
Not sure if been discussed already but `conceal_lines` makes more sense to me than `conceal_line`.

> Not sure if been discussed already but `conceal_lines` makes more sense to me than `conceal_line`.

Hasn't been discussed. Why? Because it will hide multiple lines if the range spans multiple lines? That's true for all flags, most of which aren't plural either. Keeping it singular seems more natural me, but I don't mind.
`virt_lines`? (So +1 from me to Lewis' suggestion.)

`virt_lines` itself can take an array of lines so there the plural form makes sense. Setting a `conceal_lines` property for a singular `start_row` seems wrong to me. Setting `end_row` implies that all "singular-form" properties are applied to all lines in the range. Making the property itself plural seems off.

> That's true for all flags, most of which aren't plural either. 

Which? From what I can tell, all flags are named appropriately for what they do.

> `virt_lines` itself can take an array of lines so there the plural form makes sense. Setting a `conceal_lines` property for a singular `start_row` seems wrong to me. Setting `end_row` implies that all "singular-form" properties are applied to all lines in the range. Making the property itself plural seems off.

Sorry, but `conceal_line` is not a singular property like `priority` (which would have to be called `char_priority` for that argument to hold). If a single `conceal_line` mark can skip multiple lines, it should be plural. (And the symmetry with `virt_lines` helps avoid needless mental typos.)

Not a deal-breaker, but to me the arguments are noticeably in favor of plural here.
Likewise `nvim_buf_set/get_lines` can set/get a single line, but it is named with the plural because it can set/get multiple lines.
Could add a sentence or two to `:h treesitter-highlight-conceal` (doesn't need a separate paragraph or tag).

We could instead have the on_win callback (that now already iterates from topline > botline), store captures/metadata per line, and have the on_line callback iterate that. Would that be a welcome refactor?
I'm not sure what benefit that has over using the treesitter iterator. If anything wouldn't it be less performant due to the intermediate structure?

Reduces some code duplication (~30 LOC less) and double calls to `iter()`, `get_range()`, and `unpack4()`. My assumption was that it would be more performant, but if those functions are cheap, that might not be true, IDK. I'll try to benchmark.

So yeah it's about twice as fast, even though multiline marks need to be stored in each line it spans. Otherwise multiline highlights are only applied to the start line. This doesn't seem to be tested (at least not in `treesitter/highlight_spec.lua`). Even then, it's still around twice as fast as the current PR, and also ~10% faster than HEAD. 

So yeah it seems significant work is done in the de-duplicated functions. I'll add it in a separate commit to review.

There's currently an issue with lines not being concealed if they weren't visible before other lines were concealed. I.e. for this [file.md](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/17966293/file.md), and this config:

```lua
vim.treesitter.start(0, 'markdown')
vim.cmd('set conceallevel=3')
vim.cmd('set number')
```

runnung `nvim --clean -u config.lua file.md`. 

On the first few redraws, lines at the bottom would not be concealed. Moving with `<C-d>` and `<C-u>` produces the same issues:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d035cf04-7469-456a-9ae6-1b7188340a7d)


This happens because `srow` and `erow` are determined before some lines are concealed, and concealed lines below the window are not added even though they eventually become visible. There's also no highlighting for those lines.
Thanks for noticing that, I'll look into it.

Would it be possible to run the query cursor for the entire window only if the query has `conceal_lines` (similar to how #26827 [handles combined injections](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/a092c61fd6b6f1b8cbd13bad7ada337786819a13/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/query.lua#L35)) and `conceallevel` is 3, and keep the old highlighting logic?

Query cursor is the main bottleneck for long lines, and keeping the old logic would make it possible to not run it for the entire line.

If there's a slowdown from running the highlighting query twice, we can try moving everything that needs to run for the entire window into a separate query file to reduce the number of matches.

> If there's a slowdown from running the highlighting query twice, we can try moving everything that needs to run for the entire window into a separate query file to reduce the number of matches.

That seemed the most obvious solution to me as well and I proposed it in chat but @clason didn't like that.
Nah, we should avoid that. If we need to partition them, then this should be done internally (somehow).

> There's currently an issue with lines not being concealed if they weren't visible before other lines were concealed.

Resolved this by just extending `erow` whenever we place a `conceal_lines` mark. Removed the perf refactor so as not to conflict with #31400. EDIT: This is now handled by the new decoration provider callback.

Will see if anything else can be done to improve performance for placing `conceal_lines` marks.

In addition to the new `_on_decor_line` decoration provider callback, I painstakingly went through all instances of `has(Any)Folding()` to make sure the logic handles concealed lines properly. Unless deemed necessary I don't think it worth it to add tests for all the affected code paths...
